an9.42:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an9.42:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an9.42:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an9.42:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Udāyī went up to Venerable Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.

an9.42:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an9.42:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda,

an9.42:1.4.eng: “Reverend, this was said by the godling Pañcālacaṇḍa:

an9.42:2.2.eng: was discovered by the Buddha of vast intelligence,

an9.42:2.4.eng: the sage, the solitary boss bull.’

an9.42:3.1.pli: Katamo, āvuso, sambādho, katamo sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an9.42:3.1.eng: But what is confinement, and what is the opening amid confinement that the Buddha spoke of?”

an9.42:3.2.eng: “Reverend, these five kinds of sensual stimulation are called ‘confinement’ by the Buddha.

an9.42:3.4.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
an9.42:3.4.eng: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.42:3.8.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
an9.42:3.8.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.42:3.9.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, pañca kāmaguṇā sambādho vutto bhagavatā.
an9.42:3.9.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation that are called ‘confinement’ by the Buddha.

an9.42:4.1.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:4.1.eng: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.42:4.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:4.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:4.5.pli: Yadeva tattha vitakkavicārā aniruddhā honti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:4.5.eng: Whatever placing of the mind and keeping it connected has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:5.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled … enters and remains in the second absorption.

an9.42:5.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:5.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:5.5.pli: Yadeva tattha pīti aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:5.5.eng: Whatever rapture has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:6.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture … enters and remains in the third absorption.

an9.42:6.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:6.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of creating an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:6.5.pli: Yadeva tattha upekkhāsukhaṃ aniruddhaṃ hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:6.5.eng: Whatever bliss with equanimity has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:7.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain … enters and remains in the fourth absorption.

an9.42:7.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:7.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:7.5.pli: Yadeva tattha rūpasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:7.5.eng: Whatever perception of form has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:8.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.42:8.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:8.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:8.5.pli: Yadeva tattha ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:8.5.eng: Whatever perception of the dimension of infinite space has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an9.42:9.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:9.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:9.5.pli: Yadeva tattha viññāṇañcāyatanasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:9.5.eng: Whatever perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

an9.42:10.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:10.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:10.5.pli: Yadeva tattha ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:10.5.eng: Whatever perception of the dimension of nothingness has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.42:11.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an9.42:11.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.42:11.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a qualified sense.

an9.42:11.5.pli: Yadeva tattha nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññā aniruddhā hoti, ayamettha sambādho.
an9.42:11.5.eng: Whatever perception of neither perception nor non-perception has not ceased is the confinement there.

an9.42:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.42:12.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.42:12.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sambādhe okāsādhigamo vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.42:12.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of an opening amid confinement in a definitive sense.”

an9.43:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an9.43:1.2.eng: What is the direct witness that the Buddha spoke of?”

an9.43:2.1.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.43:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.43:2.2.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
an9.43:2.2.eng: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

an9.43:2.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.43:2.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the direct witness in a qualified sense.

an9.43:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …
an9.43:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption …

an9.43:3.4.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
an9.43:3.4.eng: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

an9.43:3.5.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena.
an9.43:3.5.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the direct witness in a qualified sense.

an9.43:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.43:4.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.43:4.2.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
an9.43:4.2.eng: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

an9.43:4.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.43:4.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the direct witness in a qualified sense. Furthermore, take a mendicant who enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness … the dimension of nothingness … the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception …

an9.43:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.43:5.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.43:5.2.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
an9.43:5.2.eng: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

an9.43:5.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.43:5.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the direct witness in a definitive sense.”

an9.44:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of one ‘freed by wisdom’.

an9.44:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, paññāvimutto vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an9.44:1.2.eng: What is the one freed by wisdom that the Buddha spoke of?”

an9.44:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
an9.44:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.44:2.2.eng: And they understand that with wisdom.

an9.44:2.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, paññāvimutto vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.44:2.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the one freed by wisdom in a qualified sense. …

an9.44:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.44:3.2.eng: And they understand that with wisdom.

an9.44:3.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, paññāvimutto vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.44:3.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the one freed by wisdom in a definitive sense.”

an9.45:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, ubhatobhāgavimutto vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an9.45:1.2.eng: What is the one freed both ways that the Buddha spoke of?”

an9.45:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.45:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.45:2.2.eng: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way. And they understand that with wisdom.

an9.45:2.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, ubhatobhāgavimutto vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.45:2.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the one freed both ways in a qualified sense. …

an9.45:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.45:3.2.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya ca naṃ pajānāti.
an9.45:3.2.eng: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way. And they understand that with wisdom.

an9.45:3.3.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, ubhatobhāgavimutto vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.45:3.3.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the one freed both ways in a definitive sense.”

an9.46:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘a teaching apparent in the present life’.

an9.46:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an9.46:1.2.eng: In what way did the Buddha speak of a teaching apparent in the present life?”

an9.46:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.46:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.46:2.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.46:2.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the teaching apparent in the present life in a qualified sense. …

an9.46:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.46:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.46:3.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.46:3.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the teaching apparent in the present life in a definitive sense.”

an9.47:0.3.eng: Extinguishment Is Apparent in the Present Life

an9.47:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they say that ‘extinguishment is apparent in the present life’.

an9.47:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti?
an9.47:1.2.eng: In what way did the Buddha say extinguishment is apparent in the present life?”

an9.47:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.47:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.47:2.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.47:2.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha said that extinguishment is apparent in the present life in a qualified sense. …

an9.47:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.47:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.47:3.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.47:3.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha said that extinguishment is apparent in the present life in a definitive sense.”

an9.5:1.3.eng: The powers of wisdom, energy, blamelessness, and inclusiveness.

an9.5:1.4.eng: And what is the power of wisdom?

an9.5:1.5.pli: Ye dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā ye dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā ye dhammā sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā ye dhammā anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā ye dhammā kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā ye dhammā sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā ye dhammā sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā ye dhammā asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā ye dhammā nālamariyā nālamariyasaṅkhātā ye dhammā alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, tyassa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhā honti vocaritā.
an9.5:1.5.eng: One has clearly seen and clearly contemplated with wisdom those qualities that are skillful and considered to be skillful; those that are unskillful … blameworthy … blameless … dark … bright … to be cultivated … not to be cultivated … not worthy of the noble ones … worthy of the noble ones and considered to be worthy of the noble ones.

an9.5:1.6.eng: This is called the power of wisdom.

an9.5:2.1.eng: And what is the power of energy?

an9.5:2.2.pli: Ye dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā ye dhammā sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā ye dhammā kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā ye dhammā asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā ye dhammā nālamariyā nālamariyasaṅkhātā, tesaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an9.5:2.2.eng: One generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives to give up those qualities that are unskillful and considered to be unskillful; those that are blameworthy … dark … not to be cultivated … not worthy of the noble ones and considered to be not worthy of the noble ones.

an9.5:2.3.pli: Ye dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā ye dhammā anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā ye dhammā sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā ye dhammā sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā ye dhammā alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, tesaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an9.5:2.3.eng: One generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives to gain those qualities that are skillful and considered to be skillful; those that are blameless … bright … to be cultivated … worthy of the noble ones and considered to be worthy of the noble ones.

an9.5:2.4.eng: This is called the power of energy.

an9.5:3.1.eng: And what is the power of blamelessness?

an9.5:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako anavajjena kāyakammena samannāgato hoti, anavajjena vacīkammena samannāgato hoti, anavajjena manokammena samannāgato hoti.
an9.5:3.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has blameless conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an9.5:3.3.eng: This is called the power of blamelessness.

an9.5:4.1.eng: And what is the power of inclusiveness?

an9.5:4.2.eng: There are these four ways of being inclusive.

an9.5:4.3.eng: Giving, kindly words, taking care, and equality.

an9.5:4.4.eng: The best of gifts is the gift of the teaching.

an9.5:4.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, peyyavajjānaṃ yadidaṃ atthikassa ohitasotassa punappunaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.
an9.5:4.5.eng: The best sort of kindly speech is to teach the Dhamma again and again to someone who is engaged and who actively listens.

an9.5:4.6.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, atthacariyānaṃ yadidaṃ assaddhaṃ saddhāsampadāya samādapeti niveseti patiṭṭhāpeti, dussīlaṃ sīlasampadāya … macchariṃ cāgasampadāya … duppaññaṃ paññāsampadāya samādapeti niveseti patiṭṭhāpeti.
an9.5:4.6.eng: The best way of taking care is to encourage, settle, and ground the unfaithful in faith, the unethical in ethics, the stingy in generosity, and the ignorant in wisdom.

an9.5:4.7.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, samānattatānaṃ yadidaṃ sotāpanno sotāpannassa samānatto, sakadāgāmī sakadāgāmissa samānatto, anāgāmī anāgāmissa samānatto, arahā arahato samānatto.
an9.5:4.7.eng: The best kind of equality is the equality of a stream-enterer with another stream-enterer, a once-returner with another once-returner, a non-returner with another non-returner, and a perfected one with another perfected one.

an9.5:4.8.eng: This is called the power of inclusiveness.

an9.5:5.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi balehi samannāgato ariyasāvako pañca bhayāni samatikkanto hoti.
an9.5:5.1.eng: A noble disciple who has these four powers has got past five fears.

an9.5:5.3.eng: Fear regarding livelihood, disrepute, feeling insecure in an assembly, death, and bad rebirth.

an9.5:5.4.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an9.5:5.6.eng: Why would I be afraid of that?

an9.5:5.8.eng: the powers of wisdom, energy, blamelessness, and inclusiveness.

an9.5:5.9.eng: A witless person might fear for their livelihood.

an9.5:5.10.eng: A lazy person might fear for their livelihood.

an9.5:5.11.eng: Someone who does blameworthy things by way of body, speech, and mind might fear for their livelihood.

an9.5:5.12.eng: Someone who does not include others might fear for their livelihood.

an9.5:5.13.eng: I have no fear of disrepute …

an9.5:5.14.eng: I have no fear about feeling insecure in an assembly …

an9.5:5.15.eng: I have no fear of death …

an9.5:5.16.eng: I have no fear of a bad rebirth.

an9.5:5.17.eng: Why would I be afraid of that?

an9.5:5.19.eng: the powers of wisdom, energy, blamelessness, and inclusiveness.

an9.5:5.20.eng: A witless person might be afraid of a bad rebirth.

an9.5:5.21.eng: A lazy person might be afraid of a bad rebirth.

an9.5:5.22.eng: Someone who does blameworthy things by way of body, speech, and mind might be afraid of a bad rebirth.

an9.5:5.23.eng: Someone who does not include others might be afraid of a bad rebirth.’

an9.5:5.24.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi balehi samannāgato ariyasāvako imāni pañca bhayāni samatikkanto hotī”ti.
an9.5:5.24.eng: A noble disciple who has these four powers has got past these five fears.”

an9.50:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘extinguishment in a certain respect’. …”

an9.51:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘extinguishment in this life’.

an9.51:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti?
an9.51:1.2.eng: In what way did the Buddha speak of extinguishment in this life?”

an9.51:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.51:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.51:2.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.51:2.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of extinguishment in this life in a qualified sense. …

an9.51:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.51:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.51:3.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.51:3.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of extinguishment in this life in a definitive sense.”

an9.52:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, khemaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti?
an9.52:1.2.eng: In what way did the Buddha speak of a safe place?”

an9.52:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.52:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.52:2.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, khemaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.52:2.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of a safe place in a qualified sense. …

an9.52:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.52:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.52:3.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, khemaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.52:3.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of a safe place in a definitive sense.”

an9.53:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘reaching a safe place’. …”

an9.55:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘reaching freedom from death’. …”

an9.56:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘a place without fear’. …”

an9.57:1.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of ‘reaching a place without fear’. …”
